reviewText:
I am not a fan of tower defense or even strategy games, in general. I got this game on a bundle, and I was glad I got it, though, as the game has a characteristic that is not usually related to tower defense games: it's a relaxing game, a game about keeping it cool while fighting balls of energy that symbolize all the things that can ruin our lives.

The game lacks a tutorial (only has a brief screen explanating the keys required to play. There is no story mode, only different scenarios and in-game achievements, most of them being related to playing the game once in a higher difficulty level. The music is soothing, and the sound effects are really nice and fit the game really well.

Gameplay consists of creating units to defend your mind from the negative forces, and you can upgrade these units using the game's currency, that is, the energy you get by destroying the negative forces. There is no explanation of the advantages of each unit, but a basic rule to play the game is be to keep removing old units as soon as possible and adding better ones, until you only have the best units. Then you need to upgrade the units to be faster (up to 2s between shots) and deal more damage (not sure if there is a limit to the damage per shot for each unit), and these upgrades also cost energy.

I have not been able to play in multiplayer, as the game found no servers at the time. I will update this review if I'm able to play with someone, in the future, but the game page tells me up to three people can play at a time, and it is also possible to chat with other players, even if you are playing alone (I don't know why this is an option).

To sum up, I do recommend the game, but I must warn you that you will not have much to do in it, unless you really want to get all the in-game achievements or just need a game to play when you need to relax for some time. However, due to the lack of story, I can only recommend it if you get it in a really good sale or in a bundle (I believe a game should be reviewed as worth playing regardless of the price, as Steam has countless sales and indie games appear in countless bundles).

reviewText:
Particula is another game where I'd choose a 'maybe' option for my recommendation: it sits midway between yes and no. But in this case, I'm leaning towards no.

Particula is a very simple tower defense game. It has three levels and that's it. Each level has 25 waves of enemies, which are always the same, and that's it. And it has three different tower types, each with three different levels of effectiveness, and that's it. Upgrades to towers are also simple, with up to 10 speed upgrades (taking each tower from attacking once every three seconds at minimum to once every two seconds at maximum), and a seemingly unlimited number of damage upgrades, adding one point of damage with each upgrade.

The graphics are well done and the music is lovely. The controls are simple enough that the game doesn't need a tutorial. The game supports multiplayer, but I've not been able to find anyone else to play with, so I can't comment on that. From what I can gather from the Steam community discussions, the maps are still the same. And the game is very slow to play.

Particula was an interesting experience, but there's just not enough to it for me to recommend it. It comes with trading cards, which is a nice bonus for those interested in them, and does have in-game achievements to encourage some replayability, at least, but these are not mapped to Steam achievements, which reduces interest in them to many potential players.

With a bit more variation and Steam achievements included, I'd not hesitate to recommend Particula. As it is, however, I'm still stuck leaning towards no.

reviewText: To anyone that is feeling a little down, depressed, or low on positivity, this game provides any and all positivies to fill that void. Particula truly captures artistic style and gameplay without diminishing the overall value. As far as game mechanics, there is an incredible level of strategy in this game. Of the three different tower types, the variation is unmatched. It provides a mental...no, even physical challenge. You can really see the developers put an astronomical level of thought into their product. Just when you thought it was all over you realize you can defend your mind with up to THREE PLAYERS! From my 25 minutes of online 2-player co-op with a complete stranger (who is now my best friend!), I can only imagine how euphoric the three player experience is. The motion picture background is beautiful in the way that it tells a deep and compelling story about the presumed young boy it's based on. I'll stop there to prevent potential spoilers. My only complaint is that I cannot rate this an 11/10. Truly the best tower defense/adventure/action/story  experience 5 dollars can buy.

reviewText:
Particula is another game where I'd choose a 'maybe' option for my recommendation: it sits midway between yes and no. But in this case, I'm leaning towards no.

Particula is a very simple tower defense game. It has three levels and that's it. Each level has 25 waves of enemies, which are always the same, and that's it. And it has three different tower types, each with three different levels of effectiveness, and that's it. Upgrades to towers are also simple, with up to 10 speed upgrades (taking each tower from attacking once every three seconds at minimum to once every two seconds at maximum), and a seemingly unlimited number of damage upgrades, adding one point of damage with each upgrade.

The graphics are well done and the music is lovely. The controls are simple enough that the game doesn't need a tutorial. The game supports multiplayer, but I've not been able to find anyone else to play with, so I can't comment on that. From what I can gather from the Steam community discussions, the maps are still the same. And the game is very slow to play.

Particula was an interesting experience, but there's just not enough to it for me to recommend it. It comes with trading cards, which is a nice bonus for those interested in them, and does have in-game achievements to encourage some replayability, at least, but these are not mapped to Steam achievements, which reduces interest in them to many potential players.

With a bit more variation and Steam achievements included, I'd not hesitate to recommend Particula. As it is, however, I'm still stuck leaning towards no.

reviewText: I like the concept of destroying negative thoughts, but the game is not worth more than 24 cents to a dollar, in my opinion. Fine to get if it's on sale or in a bundle. The game is a very simplistic tower defense game. Ice towers slow the negative thoughts, fire towers burn (damage over time), and  arcane towers slow (less than ice) and poison (less damage than fire). The negative thoughts come in various sizes; the bigger it is, the more HP it has. As you defeat the negative thoughts, you get energy (the currency of the game) which allows you to upgrade towers and destroy negative thoughts more quickly and effectively. The game is easy but repetitive. Multiplayer games often take a while to play unless you're playing with friends, mostly because everyone else is playing with their friends. In short, try it out if you have friends, you have nothing to do, and it's on sale.

reviewText:
It's tower defense with an abstract environment theme. It's more like a mobile game though. I mean it's pretty simple. No big deal. Just put up towers to defend the 'head' at the end of the corridor. ♥♥♥♥ spawns at the other end and makes it's way towards the 'head'. You are supposed to protect the 'head'. If an enemy reaches the head, the head loses a life. If the head loses all lives, the level is lost. And you go to the toilet and cry.

The Good:

+ Multiple tower types
+ Tower types have different attributes
+ Towers are upgradable/demolishable (Upgrade the speed or damage of the tower, demolish tower if you need the space for something else, like another type of tower)
+ Weird nice environment
+ Music/sound effects
+ Multiple maps

The Bad:

- Well, it's boring. I can't explain it in any other way than this. I mean there is no action or anything interesting. Just plain and simple tower defense game.

The pros outweigh the cons (boringness) so I recommend it. You can play it for a couple hours straight before getting bored. Or you can play like one level per day and just chill.

reviewText:
This is my review for Particula
Particula is a game where you have to defend a person's mind against evil. You must defend against this evil with magic. There is magic that can burn, slow and poison. You earn energy when the evil is destroyed and then you can upgrade and buy more magic defense. There are many games like this but Particula has a beauty to it in some ways

Pros
Graphics and color are very beautiful and gives a sense of space, life and freedom
Difficulty was very enjoyable and I liked how even the lowest difficulty was sometimes a challenge
Flow of game After waiting for the waves to start, when you fight the spheres of evil and darkness (Rage, Oppression etc.) you feel like you've accomplished something when you finish an entire round OR game
Cons
Online Gameplay was very hard to get because there are hardly any servers on at all and any servers that are online are always filled
Speed of game was a medium speed during waves but was very slow when waiting and part of the game was just wasting time waiting to gain points or for the next wave to end/start
Levels There were only 3 different areas to play on and they seem dull after you play it once or twice
My rating
I enjoy how good it looks and feels but the gameplay wasn't very enjoyable while waiting and co-op isn't much fun. I would buy it for $1 but not any higher. I'm giving this a 4/10 so I do not recommend this game for many people.

I'm not gonna lie, I obtained this free of charge and played for the trading cards, and even with zero expectations whatsoever it was sub-par.
The game went with this kinda ridiculous new-age motif, complete with soothing music and very general, abstract statements that were trying really hard to be deep and meaningful (Clear Your Mind! That was really the only thing that made the game unique. The rest was a copypasta basic tower-defense formula, with a poor upgrade mechanic.

There is a plus. I liked how you could turn the screen.
Remember, kids- stay positive!

reviewText:
Very cute game that has the player defeat negative feelings and thoughts in order to achieve positivity - all of it packed in a tower defense. Nice for after school or after work to shake of negative thoughts by just blowing them up. ;)
The graphics are somewhat minimalistic yet very nice especially for a tower defense.

What I would like to see improvement on:
- I would like it better if towers could be directly upgraded to a higher level instead of having to delete the tower and build a new one
- It would be nice to be able to manually start waves instead of having to wait for them even if there's nothing left for you to do
- a lot more waves
- before buying a tower e.g. hovering over it should give information on what it does
- there is no pause button (at least none that I could find - so if there is one it should be easier to find)

This isn't a highly strategic tower defense like e.g. Gem Craft, yet I find it entertaining especially when one doesn't really want to concentrate too much but simply let the mind drift off a bit.
Therefore, despite of the things that I would like to see improved, I would still recommend it as a casual game. =)
